bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Elbert DeCoursey, November 7, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs DeCoursey he is writing a book on Reed and yellow fever. He inquires if it would be too late to write up the dedication ceremony for a medical journal.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Elbert DeCoursey, November 7, 1953
div1.opener:
November 7, 1953
General Elbert DeCoursey
The Director
Armed Forces Institute of Pathology
7th Street and Independence Avenue S.W.
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear General DeCoursey:
div1.p:
I have your letter of November 3. Yes, I am writing a book on the
conquest of yellow fever with special reference to the work of Walter
Reed and his associates, but not omitting the work of Finlay.

I have visited Cuba several times in this connection and at one time
did have title to Reed's Building No. 1. You may be interested in the
story of how we found it, see the reprint enclosed. I am thankful to
say that although it took a rather long time to do it, our Cuban friends
were stimulated to preserve the caseta and they dedicated it last Decem-
ber 3, after a rather complete renovation job, surrounded by a little
memorial park. I was present at the ceremony and have many pictures of
the event. I had hoped to write up the dedication ceremony for a medical
journal but became so involved in other work that this was delayed. Would
it be too late for me to offer this paper to one of our military journals?
The dedication and the nature of the memorial camp, which the Cubans
graciously call Camp Lazear, should certainly become known to all American
physicians, especially of the Medical Corps.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
